I really like the idea of a caves update. Caves can have their own new biomes such as the following:

Underground ocean: As the name implies this would be a single but truly vast cavern with gravel and so on going up to y15, water going up to y30 and the ceilings of these vast caverns going up to y55. Just like any other large biomes these vast singular caverns would span many hundreds, sometimes over 1000 blocks in each direction. In these underground oceans you will find new mobs such as electric eels (hostile) and white dolphin (passive), lots of luminescent creatures and perhaps most importantly a new item, cave slime that coats the walls and ceiling (like vines, but slimey and without any thickness so it can be placed between two touching blocks). One cave slime once harvested will drop one cave slime. This can then be placed on the face of any block which makes that face of that block act the same way as a regular slime block, however unlike a slime block you can select which face of the block has that behaviour by placing, or not placing cave slimes onto each individual face. Like vines, caves slimes will grow naturally and so can be harvested, but this will only happen when placed on a vertical face within this new underground ocean biome.

This needs to be a thing. Update after update, the underground is getting kinda boring now compared to the rest of the world, and mining keeps getting less and less necessary in Minecraft because there's a lot of sufficient loot on the surface.

Now, I am definitely asking for a bit too much, but what if we had 3-D biomes and deeper worlds? The way chunks are handled right now may have to be completely redone if we went that route. We wouldn't want to have a bunch of 16x256x16 sized chunks getting loaded and unloaded rapidly as the player explores the surface.

And how about we give mineshafts some love while were at it? They do seem rather bland nowadays. Perhaps instead of them just existing, they could have a kind of central hub that can occasionally be found on the surface, like, a big hole that goes down to the mineshafts.

Caves should also be made to contain more resources. Honestly, when was the last time you found your first diamond in a world mining? With all the chests around nowadays, its easier to find them in the chests than it is to mine them out, and same thing goes for any resouce, really.

Like, you could perhaps have a thing where resources are harder to find individiually, but instead spawn in bigger clusters. And maybe we should have more gems available to make stuff with, like a very rare gem only found near lava that has an inherent heat to it, so that when made into armor, it will light enemies on fire when they touch you, or lights anything on fire you hit when you make a tool or weapon out of it. That said, it should then also make materials like iron ore immeditately turn into ingots, though to make these not OP, they all get limits on enchantment, like maybe such a pickaxe cant be enchanted with fortune or something, though the reward would have to be big enough to make the tradeoff worth it.

Rather than creating entirely new blocks for stone variations (to help reduce inventory clutter) have stone change its tint and/or color depending in the biome like grass and water does.
Also like a previous idea where you get a fog-like effect in certain area (lava cave being smokey) similar to when you're under swamp water.

I agree that Minecraft definitely needs a Cave Update.

Here’s my list of ideas that could give players a new interest in what lies below the surface.

My first idea, (and probably the most controversial one) would be to raise the block height limit. Compared to the length and width of a Minecraft world, it’s height is really quite small. Raising the block height limit to 512 and raising the generation of terrain accordingly (sea level would now be at y-126, diamonds would generate between y-15 and y-30 etc.) The reason for this is simple. It would open up the doors for new structures and cave systems that stretch twice the size of what they were before and make the world seem much more unexplored and mysterious.

Next, I propose new types of caves. This is already a much requested feature and it makes sense, as it would diversify the underground world. Desert caves, ice caves, slime caves (a more defined version of a slime chunk, the walls could be covered in vines and maybe a new mossy stone?), giant caverns half-filled with water that stretch hundreds of blocks in either direction, crystal caves (crystals could be a rare blast-resistant light source?), spider caves found deep underground (*shiver*), coral caves in ocean biomes (could be filled with jellyfish and/or stonefish?), jungle caves (spawn near the surface and have logs generate within them to resemble giant tree roots), lava chambers, lava tubes, mushroom caves, limestone caves (limestone could be a new decorative block?)

Now, to fill up this vast space and the caves within it, here is a list of ideas for generated structures that would draw people in with the promise of loot and adventure. Abandoned underground villages (similar to ocean ruins), more fossils (fossilized dragons?), dungeons (not the cobblestone boxes that exist today but sprawling abandoned underground complexes filled with loot and mobs), lost tombs containing the relics of a forgotten time, cave paintings (with pictures of mobs such as creepers or the Ender Dragon, just for fun), giant subterranean labyrinths and my favourite, Illager Undercities, vast stonebrick cities on stilts that generate in giant ocean caverns, populated with Evokers, Vindicators, Witches, Pillagers, Illusioners and maybe some new types of illagers, they could have such features as prisons holding villagers and iron golems that you can raid and rescue, arenas, keeps, stables for Ravagers and more, the possibilities here are endless!

Another feature that would make players want to go caving would be new mobs that spawn exclusively underground, with their own unique drops and behaviors. What I think of immediately are mobs such as trolls (large slow creatures with a lot of health, and tough skin. They could drop large amounts of experience points and possibly an item used to brew resistance potions),  ice slimes, desert slimes, cave slimes (would inflict status effects such as slowness, weakness and mining fatigue respectively), Giant Cave Worms (mini bosses with acidic spit attacks that inflict nausea and/or a high level of poison), maybe a new neutral dwarf or gnome mob that you can trade with and of course, the Red Dragon (to me it seems like the perfect opportunity to add this mob as a boss that can only be found in certain underground structures.)

Some other ideas: More ores; some of these, like rubies or amethyst could be found deeper underground than diamond, but give powerful buffs when placed in beacons, like absorption or level three strength. Other ores would be to give players a bit more of a step by step progression through Minecraft. Copper could be used to craft armour and weapons, being slightly better than leather and stone respectively. It could also be used for crafting redstone wires, (vertical redstone?) Tin could be used in making redstone-activated magnets that attract items to them (this would create some very interesting redstone contraptions) Bronze could be created when tin and copper are melted together in a new type of furnace (a crucible?) Bronze armour same value as chainmail while bronze weapons would only be slightly weaker than iron. Smelting high amounts of iron with charcoal could yield steel which when crafted into armour, would be like iron armour, but with twice as much durability and a natural knockback resistance. Steel weapons would also act like iron but have more durability and have certain armour penetration values. A crucible would also open the doors to smelting together new endgame ores coming from different dimensions, which I personally think is a great thing to explore. Besides ores, some other items of interest could be climbing gear: treasure items that when equipped (possibly in a new gauntlet slot?) allows you to scale vertical walls at the cost of it being slow and that you wouldn’t be able to attack while doing it, or more Totems like the Totem of Undying that you could find in certain underground structures.

Note: I did not go into all of these ideas in-depth because this is a concept post to show what’s possible and what I think would best suit a Cave Update.

One idea I have to really intensify the cave update is to update spiders at the same time:

Make a 'Mother Spider' boss lair as a feature that can spawn as a new cave biome in addition to the regular one. Allow cave spiders to spawn naturally in these new spider lair cave biomes along with regular spiders and new baby spiders.

Make spiders actually turn sideways when they climb walls.

Make cave spiders also able to climb upside-down on ceilings (since they're smaller and presumably lighter than regular spiders).

Make spiders able to jump down at players from their climbing position on a wall, web, or ceiling, even through climbable blocks. (currently they catch themselves and climb down slowly, but they should be able to ignore the climbing state of blocks in their way if they *want* to drop down.

Allow Big spiders to spit out cobweb blocks at you to try and slow you down.

Have spiders place string vertically, by shooting it straight up at a block above them. All vertically placed string should be climbable by spiders and players like ladders, but string should hang by themselves in midair as long as the top string in a line is touching a block, not unlike vines from jungle/swamp trees.

The mother boss spider should capture everything that comes to her lair: monsters, players, everything except other spiders. When I say capture, I mean she should drop down on them, spin them around while wrapping them in a cocoon, then pull them up to stick them on the ceiling.

Her bite should cause paralysis, but when a creature is cocooned, they should still be alive, and if the cocoon is broken, they are able to walk and act like normal. Monsters should try to run from the queen spider, but never fight back. Even dogs should not attack the queen, because she does not hurt the player, only causes paralysis.

I certainly agree that a cave update is due, but I also think that combat, mostly for java edition, needs updating as well. Seeing how combat isn't as big compared to a re-work to an entire world feature, it would most definitely be fitting to combine the two. I could see Mojang taking inspiration from the "Tinkers' Construct" mod by allowing you to use the fletching and smithing tables to forge new weapons with their own unique qualities (maybe new kinds of weapons, or maybe giving already existing ones new "traits," sort of like starting enchantments and/or new abilities). As for the combat, the current snapshot where you just hold the button in for melee weapons is easy. A ravager's loot can get ravaged in seconds! Perhaps they could add this functionality to a new, weaker weapon, like a katana for example, but keep the old functionality for a heavier weapon/tool, like axes, swords, etc. If you added different weapons with different "combat modes," you'd have a fighting style for everyone, which ropes in to the possible uses for the smithing table. With these major ideas for Minecraft alone of cave transformations and a combat rewrite, the next update for Minecraft would be revolutionary!

First and foremost, the amount of blocks from surface level to bedrock must be increased. Greatly. Diamonds are harder to get to, and this gives more room to add a multitude of new content, such as...

This brings me to biome relevant caves. This can be taken in so many wonderful directions! There are plenty of people who have ideas for that.

Something I don't see mentioned as often, however, is how the underground environments should effect your character. Mining that deep just can't be safe or healthy. This is something I'd REALLY like to see: Imagine you're deep inside the ground strip mining, you mine the block in front of you and realize you've struck a luminescent mushroom cave. Suddenly, a gas emits from the hole, and you begin taking damage. You block it up and equip your "gas mask", a helmet combined with a phantom membrane, glass... or such. You see where I'm getting at? Also...

-Heat causing damage the lower you go, and based on where you are, unless you have the proper armor to protect yourself from it

-I heard someone say radiation being something you should have to protect yourself from, this can go for anything else, something creative like "Ender Sickness"

My ideas:

Copper Ore - Can be smelted for Copper Ingots, which can be crafted into wires. They work like redstone but can go up walls and on ceilings.

Ruby Ore - This is only found in new nether caves, and drops Rubies. They can be traded with zombie pigmen

Titanium Ore - When smelted, this gives you titanium Ingots. This can make tools and armour. They have the highest durability, but are only as efficient as Iron Tools.

Drill - This has to be charged up before mining, but it mines very quickly when it does. This can be crafted with 3 iron and 6 redstone.
Specific Enchantments:
* Quick Charge - Takes less time to charge up before mining.

Fossils - These have a low chance of dropping from regular stone blocks, and can be traded with researcher villagers in underground villages (check my next comment)

I’ll do a second comment because of the word limit

New Mobs:

Miner - These spawn in mineshafts and will trade materials (other than emerald) with you for good mining equipment.

• Sinkholes you have to watch out for. Some pits are have a solid block at the bottom and are only deep enough to deal 2 hearts of fall damage. Others are much deeper, but have water in them. You won't die, but now you are thrown of your course and have to dig yourself out.
  • Karst caves. These come in different shapes and sized, but tend to be wide and winding with tall ceilings. Their walls are made out of diorite, limestone. Limestone can be crafted into chalk. Chalk is used for freehand drawing on eligible blocks. Hold down the right mouse button while holding some chalk in your hand to draw. Might wanna draw some arrows in caves so you're sure to find a way out.
  • Ice Caves. These are very dangerous. Look closely and you will notice that some Ice Blocks are cracked. Stand on it a bit and it breaks, so you have to make haste. But ice is slippery so rushing to much might make you slide right into a death trap as clefts, crevices and fissure are many. Even worse, you may encounter a Wampa. Wampa is a deadly white giant with a fierce attitude. Just ask Luke Skywalker.

• Atmospheric elements. Soda straws, stalagmites, flowstone, batcaves, fungi, vines. And can you find a rare Desert Rose crystal? It's coral, but made out of gypsus.
  • Sixlegger mob. Sixlegger resembles a Polar Bear, but has six legs. These solitary creatures wander around the caves looking for mushrooms, Glowfish and minerals to lick. He evolved in caves so his white eyes are almost blind. Bright light is painful for Sixlegger so he will promptly run away from bright light sources, even a torch held in hand. You will finally implement dynamic light, right? Sixleggers fur accumulates phosphorus from all the Glowfish he eats so it emits a dim glow with a green tint. Sixleggers is aggressive in the dark and will chase you to the best of his ability. He also sometimes stands on his back legs and then drops a heavy attack on you that inflicts Stun.
  • Speleologist. A Wandering Trader of caves. The only person to trade you a helmet with a mounted light source.

• Climbing equipment. A fast and easy way to move down cliffs. Uses slime balls to craft so not easy to get for a lot of explorers.
  • More depth. Currently you can get to y12 in 5 minutes and start stripping for diamonds. Wooden, golden, iron equipment is mostly useless. Making caves deeper and more challenging will emphasize the rarity of diamond and will make explorers stick to iron more. Lower levels become progressively hotter and require heat management. Heat makes your satiation decrease faster, decreases you walking, mining and attack speed and decreases damage. To counter heat you need gear with heat resistance and cooling potions.
  • Cave maps. I really don't know how to properly implement this, but I would love them.

Mojang,

There is a lot of support for a cave update, and people have submitted a lot of ideas what should go into a cave update. Because of this I want to give my specific input and opinions on a cave update. I have submitted other feedback, but in my opinion a cave update is the most needed of any possible change.

There are five elements I believe are essential to the success of a cave update:

 

1. Biomes and Layers

Biomes are the most obvious element of a cave update. There are lots of possible biomes that could be added, but some are less needed than others. And there's always the issue of how these biomes integrate with surface biomes, if at all.

I think the best way to implement biomes in caves is with layers. Vertically, the world would be split into three biome spaces: Surface, Upper, and Lower. Surface would be reserved for the biomes we already know. Upper would include some surface biomes and most cave biomes. Lower would include regular caves and some rarer or more exotic caves. Note that surface biomes may extend down to the Upper cave space. The lower layer should be composed of harder stone, to encourage cave exploration.

There are lots of options for biomes, but I think these biomes are necessary:

  1. Slime Caves - The slime chunks thing feels arbitrary. If slimes spawn underground they should either spawn everywhere, or there should be a way to visually identify "hey, slimes can spawn here".
  2. Lava Tube Caves - We find lava all the time when exploring caves, but it usually lacks structure with the rest of the cave, and is mostly limited to a specific level. And making lava exclusive to these biomes would make the path to the Nether more interesting.
  3. Fossile Caves - We hardly ever see fossils. They're there, but we don't see them often. A neat way to make better use of this structure would be to have caves with an abundance of fossils protruding from the walls.  

 

2. Generation and Structures

Overall, the appearance of caves needs an upgrade. They are small, repetitive, and seem messy. Cave tunnels need to be more varied and often larger. There also need to be more recognizable structures besides ravines, and ravines themselves need more variance: For example, they could generate at odd angles, or have a wider range of lengths and widths.

Dungeons could also use an upgrade, but I think people have hashed that out enough elsewhere I don't need to go in depth.

 

3. Sea Level

Going along with the idea of larger cave generation is the idea we need more space for caves to exist in. If sea level were higher, caves would have more space. The ocean would also benefit, as it could be deeper. And this shouldn't be too difficult to do, since build limit is so high.

This would also allow for more layers to the underground space. So instead of just having Surface, Upper, and Lower biome levels, like I mentioned, there could be an additional Middle biome level, to help better indicate the progression of depth as the player descends.

 

4. Ores

A lot of people are suggesting adding tons of different ores with a cave update. I personally think this is unnecessary. Minecraft isn't Terraria. There is value in simplicity. That said, I wouldn't oppose the addition of one or two new ores if they add something interesting besides another tier of armor and tools. What I do think needs an overhaul is how existing ores are distributed.

One big problem with the current system is that ore quantities simply increase the further down you are. Thus the ideal depth to mine is always Y = 11. I would prefer if, with the addition of cave biomes, ore generation was more biome-dependent. Not just in terms of overall quantity, either, but in terms of the optimal Y level to dig at. In mountainous terrain, perhaps diamonds would occur more often around level 30. Or perhaps coal should be harder to find, except under a desert biome. Or redstone could occur more often at the edges of a lava cave biome. The point is to make mining more interesting and allow players to target specific ores they need with different mining techniques.

In particular, iron needs to be a little harder to obtain. There is no point to getting leather armor because iron is so easy to get: You just punch a tree, make a wood pick, make a stone pick, and dig down a little. This is a survival game. Leather armor should be the go-to armor at the start of the game because it should be significantly easier to obtain a surface resource than a cave resource.

 

5. Mobs

A lot of people are also suggesting adding a ton of different mobs. I agree we need more mobs exclusive to caves, but I have no strong preference for any specific one. These mobs should be more difficult to fight than your typical overworld mobs because they should present a challenge to geared up players. In general I think the further down you go the more difficult and aggressive they should be.

 

- -

It's arguably too easy to find diamonds, and it would be compelling to have different ores that have similar durability or efficiency, while leaving diamonds as the ultimate ore.  For example, titanium (a popularly suggested new ore) could possess a similar or identical efficiency to diamonds but lack a comparable durability (or vice versa).  Deepening the world would also provide a greater context for diamond's rarity.  Adding heat deep underground (that may require fire protection armor) or radiation that give damage to the player adds a necessary game risk that even peaceful mode cannot avoid.

 

I would love to see how caves and the underground of minecraft can be drastically improved.  It will make the journey and the adventure of the game that much more of a compelling challenge.

I think working on caves is a great way to create a better progression inside of Minecraft. It's been a little bit off lately but I think making it a more difficult challenge to navigate your way to diamonds and obsidian - it would make crossing dimensions feel like more of a feat like I assume was the intent, and also just overall fulfill a lot more accomplishment once you've gone into the post-game challenges. And I don't think focusing too much on caves really makes people want to not do the other fun aspects of the game like building or farming, either - in fact, I think a slower and more fine-tuned progression using caves could actually encourage players to take their time and explore and build on the world around them.

Although people have suggested adding new ores and gems blindly, it is one of my main problems with most mod packs. Blocks with no real use will only serve to be an annoyance once the novelty wears off as Andesite, Diorite, etc. were. Aesthetic enhancements are only fine as long as they don't interfere with the original utility of a system. The main reason to go caving is to get as much ore as possible.

Having said that, I do believe it can be made a more exciting experience if done right.

My contributions pt.2.:

Items:

  • Hook: found in deep underground dungeons (chest)
  • Grappling hook - crafted with rope/lead and hook
  • Dungeon torch - on sidewalls, can be reignited by rightclicking with a torch
  • Dynamite sticks and dynamite arrows
  • Locked chests and keys to open them (iron)
  • Chemiflourescent jelly - dropped by glowing fish, sea pickles, glowing mushrooms
  • Unique armour and weapon variants found in chests (e.g. Iron armour with an exclusive skin)
  • Enchanted books or potions for treasure vision
  • Light source helmet - not a mining helmet!
  • Poisonous plants - jungle caves
  • Crystals - (not able to craft armour)
  • Glowing mushrooms
  • Glowstick - throwable, with slime becomes sticky, made with chemiflourescent jelly

Blocks:

  • New ore textures - Resemble real ore (Reddish stone - iron, greenish stone - copper...)
  • Hard stone - bluish, contrasts beautifully with lava (+gold)
  • Red dirt - around iron ore areas, would make a nice colour palette with vegetation (jungle,surface caves?)
  • Wet stone - slippery and fragile stone variant, makes stalagtites and stalagmites, waterdrops
  • Wet pillar - form stalaktites, fence like form, wet stone texture and properties, waterdrops
  • Stalaktite - grass type item, no drops, forms on the downside of wet stone and pillar, waterdrops
  • Acid - liquid, bedrock level, melts every block
  • Fossils - undrground deserts and sea-caves, give nautilus shells
  • Tree roots - obtained with silktouch
  • Changes:
  • Trident is obtained by slaying all three Elderguardians (3 spikes + 2 prismarine shards)

I haven't read all the 600+ comments that are already here, so I'm probably repeating a lot but here's what I would like to see (granted some of if not most of this is stolen from mods that already exist):

- Stalagmite and Stalgtite: mentioned probably millions of times already

- Cave Biomes: again mentioned a lot

- Larger Caves: I'd LOVE to see Larger caves in general, not bigger cave systems but giving caves a larger diameter. One mod that really impressed me doing something like this was Worley's Caves Mod. I loved exploring much larger caves and coming across a massive area underground where a few different caves came together to create a giant empty, well cave xD.

- Underwater Lakes/Flooded Caves: We already have caves that are flooded with water in ocean biomes, why not extend this to any biome? Make it a tad more rare to find a flooded cave and maybe if your lucky you'll find one of those massive empty cave sphere areas I was on a tangent about that just so happens to have an underground lake in it!

- Dense Ores: I think this would be another good addition, after a while Mining just gets to be pretty monotonous and boring. Occasionally finding a dense ore inside a ore vein that'll reward you with 2-3 times the amount of ore for a single block could really spice up mining a bit, without breaking the style of Minecraft or having the need of adding more ores.

I'll admit that I'm not as invested in a cave update as these other people, but I'd still be interested to see some improvement to cave systems since it could add some interesting ideas to the game. If you are one of the people who don't want to add any new features to the game like me, here are my ideas for improving caves down below.

1. Add more variety to the walls, floors, ceiling, etc. Currently, inside of naturally spawning caves, we have 6 blocks that can spawn for visual aesthetics: Dirt, stone, andesite, diorite, granite, and sometimes gravel. Honestly, they're not exactly topping the charts on popularity. Adding something like patches of obsidian at the y level lava naturally spawns anyway would break up the monotonous repetition of endless stone that players have to travel through in caves. It doesn't even have to be more blocks added to the game, it just needs to be anything other than endless stone.

2. Mineshafts. Yeah, they're great as structures, but they haven't been updated since they've been put in the game, and they aren't too keen on variety. Overall, mineshafts are sort of pointless since they are usually aren't worth risking the cave spider spawners and thousands of other mobs between players and Diamonds. I'd also like to add, if possible, an "official entrance" to mineshafts so that it's less a matter of randomly finding the mineshafts and more of "where to look".

This is a topic that I have very strong feelings about. Mining used to be the main way to get ores, but now we have buried treasure, desert and jungle temples, mansions, sunken ships, underwater ruins, and nether fortresses, to name a few. With all of these ways to get loot is there a real reason to mine? In a short answer NO! Of course not, these new ways to get ores are easier, more entertaining, and can often yield better loot. Now compare that to mining: it’s difficult, dangerous, and often tedious. A cave update would give us a reason to mine again as the very name of the game suggests we should be doing, it’s literally called Mine-Craft. Every update we get involved crafting but we haven’t gotten any major changes to Mining in MINEcraft. I love Minecraft in so many ways I can hardly describe it, and I am not in any way shape or form saying that Minecraft is not a good game. All I am saying is that Minecraft needs to build its self up in the mining department. Many people myself included feel very strongly about the matter of a cave update. I mean, what, ten thousand some votes That’s Absolutely Insane! Also when I say cave update I don’t mean different spawn rates in different biomes, no I’m talking about new ores, new structures, new mobs, new functions, new tools, and maybe even a new boss.

My ideas for a cave update would include cobalt, which would be found exclusively in slime chunks but in big amounts below y48, which can be used for enhancements. Enhancements would be like enchantments except you combine a tool/armor piece and a scroll and they wouldn't stack. Enhanced items can't be enchanted, and enchanted items will lose their enchantments once enhanced to balance it. Enhancements would include Strength, Sustainment, and Speed (more damage, more durability, and faster use time, respectively).

This post has been around for a long time so I think I should throw my two cents into the matter.

Mojang, don't be afraid to add "useless" features. I know people tend to wine when a block doesn't really do anything, but we builders would appreciate new blocks like Maw Sit Sit or Basalt to build out of.

Give tools/armor special buffs. I feel like Diamond armor should always have the highest durability/protection, but other materials could have their own buffs, like how Gold tools dig faster and Turtle Shells let you breathe underwater. Perhaps Sapphire armor could give you the luck buff and Fire Opal armor could make you immune to fire damage.

Make things biome specific. The underground in Minecraft is both cluttered and boring. Adding variety to caves by biome will help with inventory management and add incentive to explore. Peridots could  be desert exclusive for example. 

The Nether should have a higher amount of Quartz and Igneous rocks than the Overworld. Stuff like Amethyst, Bloodstone, or Basalt wouldn't necessarily be Nether exclusive, but would be much more common there. Would add extra incentive to live/mine there.

Here are some ideas for new ores that can come to the game to enrich gameplay!

It is difficult to add new ores to the game, as you don’t want to affect the balance between existing. In my opinion, diamonds have always been and should always be the strongest and rarerest resource to find. None of its current properties should be changed, and I think that new ores should be built around the current properties of existing ones. Here are a few of my ideas:
Copper - Similar rarity to iron, but is slightly stronger yet slows the player down.
Silver - Is slightly rather than Copper/Iron, and can be used to create armor, but maybe it could possibly be more applicable to redstone. Maybe instead, silver can only be used to craft redstone entities like repeaters and comparators. Maybe copper and silver can create different speed variants of powered rails compared to the gold ones!
Tin - Tin can be weaker than iron, but when crafted with iron can create steel, which is a much stronger building alternative and can only be used to craft stell tools and armor. The tools/armor would be much stronger and long lasting than iron, but harder to repair or enchant.
Pearl - Can only be found in deep floors of ocean biomes, but are incredibly valuable for trading.
Uranium - Can he found in rare areas of caves, and are extremely hazardous. Maybe they can cause radiation/poisoning when in a certain radius, and have a small chance of exploding when mined. Uranium can be used to create Radiatiors that poison mobs, or can enhance TNT to make it much more powerful and damaging. To contrast -
Lead - Lead is as rare as gold/redstone, but can be used to fight against poisoning and radiation. If lead armor/tools are used for too long, it can maybe cause a poison effect as well.

I think that adding things like crystal formations and more gemstone ores would be a great addition to caves, and it would definitely add a sense of fantasy and magic while still being dark and ominous. Possibly adding new mobs both hostiles and dociles, and new tools and armor would be cool

@TippiestComet63

I agree with the idea of making the geology more realistic. Currently the only distinguishing factors between elevations, besides the technical Y value, are "is there a lot of lava rivers" and "can strongholds spawn". It's really quite boring, honestly, and as I stated in my previous comment, hasn't changed in like, 7 years. So much has been added to the surface, oceans, and even The End, yet despite the game being MINEcraft, mining has been relatively unchanged. But I digress.
Back to your suggestion about geology, I seem to recall a Forge mod from 1.7 that did something to this effect. I forget the name of it but it was used as part of the Blightfall pack and added several new types of stone. Instead of just stone, diorite, stone, andesite, granite, stone (yes I said stone 3 times), and (as a lot of other mods have added) marble & basalt, there were some new ones and even a few completely alien types (fitting, considering that pack was set on an alien planet), all of which could be categorized into one of the three major types of rock that are arguably central to geology: metamorphic, igneous, and sedimentary. It really gave the environment a more natural, realistic feel to it.

Edit: found the name! It was called Underground Biome Constructs, and added like 13 or so types of rock for each of the 3 categories

1. Raise the height limit again, anywhere from 64-256 blocks to accommodate for larger caves and a deeper underground
2. Put sea level at a higher level, respective to how high you raise the world height limit
3. Allow items such as cobblestone, stone, snow, sand, sandstone dirt, gravel, granite, andesite, diorite, and other common blocks to stack anywhere from 128-256 per stack, allowing for extra inventory space for things like current and new ores
4. Add another 9 inventory slots, and/or a craftable backpack or loot bag to help carry gems and ores
5. Biome specific caves with biome specific blocks. I would love to see the underground snowy tundra be filled with packed snow (a new block idea) and ice/packed ice, or the badlands with terracotta layered far underground. That alone would help caves have a unique flavor to them

6. Make the bottom 25-50 blocks (depending on how high the world height limit is raised) a hardened stone, that is much harder to mine, making strip mining less viable
7. Along with #6, rework ore generation. Instead of making all ores generally more common the deeper you go, add layers. Allow diamonds to spawn commonly at the deepest levels, and iron to be more common at mid levels. Make ore pockets less common but much larger
8. I would love to see vast caverns (by the magnitude of 10-50 blocks tall and 50-500 blocks long/wide, similar to how ravines spawn at different sizes) where lots of ores are exposed and mobs can spawn. Large, spacious caves that are hard to light would make it exciting but challenging without proper gear
9. Add a difficulty curve to depth, or add an optional mode where the deeper underground you go, the tougher mobs get, adding to the challenge of venturing for more precious ores and blocks
10. Add some more ores, please! Add a new function to the blast furnace as well, where you input two ingots of differing metals to create new allows (similar to how brewing works) Ores like copper, which drops a dust and can be used in tandem with redstone functions, being able to be used directly next to redstone but not connect to it. Zinc, tin, platinum, onyx, and other new and unique metals that can be combined to create alloys like steel and titanium. Please make gold useful too! It's virtually worthless in terms of tools and armor

11. Add some more gems, like red beryl, sapphire, and crystal, which can be used as different currency to trade with villagers, in enchanting, and can be used in beacons to provide different effects
12. Along with #10 and #11, it's okay if you introduce new ores and wait a patch or two to give them a proper function, just like you did with Lapis Lazuli and enchanting
13. I don't think any new ores or gems should be better than diamond. Diamond is, and always should be the best. Just make it harder to come by. It should be rare and exciting to get! Not obtainable in 5 minutes of gameplay
14. Get rid of water/ lava lakes. They are everywhere, and honestly kind of annoying when caving. Give the deep underground a haze like feature, where visibility, especially near lava, is slightly reduced
15. Mini underground biomes, like small gem rooms, or bioluminescent green mushrooms

16. New mobs, like a wraith, glowing bats, bats that turn into vampires when attacked, large undead rats, underground miner, walking armor (an invisible mob that wears random pieces of armor to be seen) Improve spider pathfinding. They get stuck too often. A new queen spider miniboss in the dirt room in abandoned mineshaft
17. I would love to see the lighting engine reworked to allow for colored torches, made with glowstone and dyes
18. Rework the wandering trader. His trades are almost all useless
19. Some people suggested underground villages. This might be cool, but it would really be done well if the world height limit was raised, and caverns were created as mentioned in #8
20. Give villager jobs blocks a use. Fletching table for making tipped arrows out of different metals and potions (giving metals a lot more use and unique qualities), the smithing table to infuse armor with gems, etc
21. Get rid of all the small pockets of things like gravel, dirt, andesite, granite, and diorite underground, and instead make them hundreds to thousands of blocks, even generating as their own mini cave biomes

Adding some things that could make mining a bit more dangerous and exciting would make mining & spelunking much more fun and potentially more rewarding (ex. a high-risk, high-reward scenario). I'm not suggesting anything too drastic, just different biomes or differently-generated caves, perhaps. As for the danger, new cave-specific mobs (mobs that don't spawn above a certain Y) would be phenomenal. Other things such as quarries, which could be uncommon generations found above ground, would add a layer of realism that I believe the game is currently lacking in. In that same vein (ha!), adding dig sites (and maybe some variants for variety) could add in more danger, say, with TNT. Adding TNT to a new kind of underground dig site would not only make it more realistic, but give a new way to find TNT, since right now, players can only locate it naturally under desert temples. It could be added to abandoned mineshafts as well, all-in-all adding another level of risk and reward to the game. Maybe there could even be some non-abandoned mineshafts, who knows?

But really. The game is called "Minecraft," after all, and most players spend a ton of time in caves. (Not to mention that Minecraft was originally named "Cave Game.") Caves are an intrinsic part of the game, but they haven't been changed much at all since the game was out of alpha, (besides the addition of granite, andesite, and diorite). It's been the better part of a decade now, and caves have been essentially untouched (the same goes for strongholds, but that's a different conversation). The Update Aquatic and upcoming Nether Update are giving exactly the kind of love to the oceans and Nether that caves need, and they are proof that the Mojang team is capable of improving caves. I'm not here to rant like others might be, I'm here because I love this game and want to see it become the best it can be. Mojang, millions of people agree that Minecraft is amazing, and you have always shown the continuous dedication to improve upon it. I know that many people in the community have been laying on a ton of pressure for a cave update (and the return of 1.8.9 pvp, which I'd also love, but that again is another conversation), and I know that you can't please everyone. Living up to the expectations, especially with a game and fanbase as massive as this one. But, I'd argue that the majority want the cave update, and you'd probably rake in revenue.

So, that's my spiel. Whether you are going to add a cave update or not remains to be seen, and I'm not here to make the decision for you. At the end of the day, I'm probably just another voice in the crowd. But if you got this far, whether you're on Mojang's team or just another player like me, thank you.

Something I see being profitable for a Cave Update is moving the world generation, like 32 to 64 blocks upward. Sure, it doesn't seem like a lot, but take into consideration that the height limit is currently 256 blocks. Most biomes only use up to about 30% of that space - by adding a deeper underground, more of that space could be spent by feeding worlds with juicy, newly generated content.

From a technical standpoint, I understand this being difficult. Temperature and sea level systems need to be tweaked, plus old worlds would be completely nonconvertible. If it could be figured out, that would be amazing!

I would really love to see some of these changes:

- More types of dungeons (something more challenging than just square room with spawner and chests)

- Underground water/lava rivers with waterfalls (not just 1 random block... rivers should appear with randomized size, and their generation should somewhat look like in overworld, but with more "freedom" on Y axis)

- Small clefts inside caves (like canyons but 2-3 blocks wide)

- Water flooded caves (should have decent borders, which might be hard to code)

- Geysers (geyser blocks are the same as stone, but with small difference on top texture; they deal damage with sneaky eruption and throw player into air ~ you can't collect them even with silk touch, they will drop a regular stone/cobblestone)

- Ore-specific caves (for example, Iron Caves, with more Iron inside)

- Webs which behave like spawners but at very slow rate ( for example, 1 spider / 1 minecraft day)

- Gas blocks (same as air, but causes chain of explosions if touches anything hot like lava/fire/torch etc) They appear almost invisible (hard to see) until you drink Night Vision Potion. With this potion effect you might see cloudy effect going on, indicating gas.
You can also use flint and steel to burn these blocks, but be careful since it explodes right away, and surrounding gas blocks explode as well. Explosion deals less damage to creatures (compared to TNT) but more damage to blocks causing them to disappear completely without any drop

Hey Mojang.

I have a few ideas for this upcoming (hopefully) update that includes a few ideas for cave generation, structures, mobs and gameplay aspects:

-This is a big one: I don't know much about coding, and I'm not gonna pretend I do, but what I do know is that the nether generates spectacularly. So, I was wondering if you could incorporate that into the cave generation system (obviously replacing the netherrack with stone etc.). As well as making it so that not only does the terrain infinitely generate on the x and z axes but also on the y-axis, allowing this nether generation effect to be amplified the deeper you go. And also maybe making it so that only starts about 1 or 2 hundred blocks below ground so that the classic caves are also there, and you don't immediately drop into a vast lava-filled cavern.

-Now these are some mobs that maybe you guys can add: Worms that swallow blocks and attack the player (found deep), stone golems that can only be crafted with a special ore, and are vulnerable to pickaxes, villagers underground that trade you rare resources in exchange for things only found aboveground and a whole host of hostile and passive mobs

-It would also be really cool to see some classic structures get refurbished, such as dungeons and abandoned mineshafts by adding some traps and changing the look and size, as well as adding things like underground civilizations where those villagers and maybe even stone golems can be found.

-This has a bit to do with the first one, but it would also be pretty awesome if there were different types of underground biomes, such as the huge lava filled caverns, narrow but long caves, worm nests and maybe even super rare ore pockets filled with magnificent crystals.

-Some new ores would be really nice to add too, like citrine, turquoise and amethyst as well as some made up ones crystals as well. With uses such as being crafted into armor, weapons, and maybe even consumables as well as adding different types of furnaces and fuels capable of smelting different ores.

-And lasts but not least: Traps that set off rolling stones which chase after the player, damaging blocks that they run into. This would serve as a cool touch and a homage to a classic movie.

 

It would be really cool to see some of this added to the game, and I hope this comment finds you well.

Add a potion that can track down ores. When you drink it and you're in a 20 block radius of an ore, there will be particles that's the same color as the nearest ore and the particles will fall out of blocks that you need to mine to get to the ore. Think of the particles like a checkpoint and you're going to each checkpoint until you hit the finish line.

A Rewarding Cave Progression System

Instead of just adding new items and ores into the game, I think it would be awesome to see if we can bring a different aspect into the world of Minecraft. In the Overworld, you can spawn anywhere and be equally challenged in each biome. However, once you become stronger and more equipped, you will start to venture off and create the Nether portal which will give you access to a new challenge, and then the End and so on. With a new caves update, it would be fun to not only explore bigger biomes, but have different difficulty in each cave biome. For example, there could be an underground cave spider nest which has a ton of good loot from "unfortunate traveling villagers". But you decide not to go into that nest just yet because you're not equipped enough to take on that many spiders at once. So you decide to explore the cave system and figure out which layers you are able to access with your tools and armor stats. Heck, maybe there could even be a new "flaming arrow" due to the nether update with the soul fire in the 1.16 snapshot where you put an arrow and soul fire torch in a crafting bench. This could be the cave spiders' weakness and you and your friends battle it out and finally get to the multiple cave spider spawners enveloped in webs and in the center of those spawners are high tier loot. 

Basically what I'm saying is, Minecraft is such a great game and I've been playing it all my life. Instead of just adding new items and cool things to the game, I'd like to see a challenging progression system within the caves where players need to strategize and overcome rewarding challenges within the caves. I don't know if it's possible, but maybe even lowering the bedrock Y value level could help add space for new possibilities.

Shimmering caves

A nice addition to cave update would be a new type of cave: shimmering cave. It would contain a new ore: shimmerock (there could be a better name for it). It would look like stone block with lots of small light blue rocks in it and it would emit a moderate amount of light, making the cave slightly lit.

The shimmerock ore could only be mined with silk touch, otherwise it would drop shimmerock as an item. As an item it could be used in three different ways:
1. A new light source: to make a lamp. Similar to a redstone lamp, but it would have different appearance and a bluish light.
2. Shimmerock torch. It would be similar to a redstone torch and could power things and would have a bluish top. But it would be the only way to power things - no block like redstone block, and no powder to make a trail.
3. To make a new potion. The effect would be to make you glow in the dark for some time: there would be a radius of light surrounding you.

The ore itself could be used to provide a growing environment for white mushrooms (read below) and also it would be a nice decorative block.

White mushrooms. They would grow in shimmering caves and would have ghostly appearance. In order to grow they must be within the light radius of the shimmerock ore.
These mushrooms could be used in four ways:
1. Additional food source for mushroom stews.
2. It could be used in composter and would have a high level of compost-ability, making them quite useful. But they would be rare, so they wouldn't be overpowered.
3. To make a new potion which could make you invisible to phantoms for a few minutes.
4. For decoration.

There was a comment by Mc Rat that I'd like to elaborate on. 

He mentioned the progression system of ores and he had a wonderful idea of a layer of rock that needs to be broken to increase how deep you can travel.

Now imagine, making the underground deeper, I mean way deeper, and adding layers of rock, perhaps 3-4 blocks deep that can only be broken by a certain pickaxe. So perhaps the first layer is a rock, let's call it "Stonerite" And it spawns at around 15-20 blocks below the surface across the Overworld. This block is impossible to break with a wooden or stone pickaxe, and a new ore is needed, 'Copper'. Now copper will allow you to create tools and armour and is slightly better than stone, but less so then Iron. The only ore found in the stonerite level is copper and coal.

Now we break the stonerite layer, here we will find copper, iron and coal. Now, this continues for another 20-25 blocks until there is a new layer of which requires iron to break. You can make the ores required to break the layers rare on their respective layers and more common the deeper you delve.

Let's say after iron you need gold or a new type of iron like black-iron or even steel to break the next layer after the iron layer. These are just some quick thoughts, you'd also need to implement caves on top of this as well but I think it adds some progression. I don't think you would be able to break the layer blocks with TNT either.

I've seen a few comments mentioning gems or crystal formations in biome specific caves and would love to see a tie in from another post regarding a volcano biome. 

My general idea is that gem caves would spawn under volcanic biomes and gems would have a rarity similar to emerald. The gems would act as a greater version of lapis lazuli and allow the player to force a stronger enchantment by placing it in the enchanting table alongside their item. Possibly showing more enchantments on the preview and giving a better idea of what you'll get for your levels. As a way to balance the feature I would make those enchantments cost more XP levels. As an extra layer of difficulty they could make netherite items only enchantable via the gems. The power creep in the game has been stagnant for a very long time and I think the addition of more materials would make advancing more challenging by introducing a small amount of grinding that hasn't been present in Minecraft in a while.

Another possible feature would be gem variations. Different colored gems would guarantee certain enchantments like red gems giving fire resistance, fire aspect, or flame; blue gems being associated with water-centric enchantments and so on.

This might be too convoluted but I've seen Minecraft's enchanting become easier over the years and believe the system has made enchanting less special than it should be.

Caves should have more reason to explore them and more reason to go mining in different biomes. This should be in the form of exclusive building and crafting materials, or at least far easier access. Each biome should also have mobs which offer their own challenges. E.G.

Smokestone Caverns: Flatter, wider caves and caverns with smokestone: a block that lowers light emission from light sources, and increases chances of mobs spawning. Icy Caves: Wide open spaces, divided by walls of ice. Could have Mirrored Ice to disorient players, and a new ore: Frost Shards. These could be used in potions to give the freezing effect, which would slow entities and damage them over time. More Biome Ideas:

Collapsing Caves: Tall caverns, and winding caves that pass over one another, filled with floating patches of gravel that may fall at a moments notice. Could also include Crumbling Stone veins - hey look like normal stone, but if you stand on them too long the veins suddenly turn into gravel and fall out from beneath you! Adds another element of danger akin to Infested Stone. Potions of Slow Falling would therefore be very handy if mining here.

Ancient Caves: Filled with swirling mists and strange fungi, beware of where you tread for you never know what status effect something may give you. Should be able to find an exclusive new ore that allows you to gain better enchantments than Lapis. 

Dwarven Ruins: Basically the Mines of Moria. Deep abandoned halls where you can find ancient chests and hoards of gems, but beware, these halls were abandoned for a reason!  But who knows what fell creatures have overrun these once beautiful cities. Banners and beds may be found here.

I think the best thing that could be done with caves should be a better generating system. I live out in the county and we have a little saying about random back roads, "looks like they followed a drunk cow when building this road!" That is my thought on current mineshafts, they just go all over the place with no logic aside from sometimes having a wooden bride over a ravine. Caves themselves should be random but they should also have a bit more logic to them. Caves generating in different ways in different areas would change where to build your base matter all the more. Maybe some areas could be more abundant with coal, iron, gold, lapis and Redstone with an area preferring to generate one resource over the others. This would make the place you decide to go mining in actually matter. As it is now, the only choices in how/where you mine are: go deep and strip mine for diamond/emerald, explore caves randomly or strip mine higher up for common materials and just quarry out a chunk for everything. If you found an area rich with iron you'd probably strip mine the heck out of that place and be set on iron for a while but you'd still need to explore other regions to accumulate other resources.

Certain mobs spawning in greater numbers depending on region would also make each area unique and go hand in hand with a good rebalance of mob spawns. Maybe there should be natural cave openings in the world, like a small, cobblestone mound that's opened up into the ground where bats like to be since they can also there during the day and come out at night.

It would be interesting if caves generated "Player Structures."  Common things Minecraft players do while caving generating naturally would add the weird feeling that someone else has been here in a single player world.  Some possible examples:

Partially constructed nether portals frames.

A crafting table, furnace, and chest spawning in a line against a cave wall or in the bottom of a ravine.  The chest could be filled with common "out mining" stuff. Cobble stone, stone variants, torches, sticks, damaged tools no greater than iron and unenchanted, biome specific items if applicable. (it's not about the loot, it's about the feeling that another player was there.)

1x2 tunnels.  Would spawn either as one tunnel or a small group 2 blocks apart. Always start in a cave and may also end in one.  End once reach a distance selected from a range or when they encounter another cave, whichever is smaller.

Ruined castles are also abandoned

The ominous tone of your writing really gives this suggestion some flair. I would very much like to see this in the game, but for another reason: Building a castle in Minecraft that is actually a decent size is a huge project that can take days, and I don't mean the 20-minute ones. If this were implemented, it would only require a simple conquering and touch-up to have a castle to call one's own.

Perhaps the size can vary as well, from a single tower to a sprawling compound. There could even be a snowy village near or within the walls that would generate as a secondary structure. Maybe the villagers need help throwing down the tyrant king, or they need to be cured of the zombie plague. Maybe the castle could have collapsed sections, blasted-out walls and floors, booby traps, secret rooms, puzzles, you name it. It could even have parts that have since been buried or overgrown and need excavating or a massive dungeon system underground. Maybe you could find an enchantment table library or even a brewery, perhaps even a broken Nether or End Portal. You could find armor stands with potentially enchanted armor and weapons on them or chests with valuable loot. One might even find a Dragon Egg and a few heads of various mobs laying about the place - a testament to hard-won battles before the castle inevitably fell. There could even be a cemetery!

To sum it up, I think this idea has a lot of potential and could very well end up being a favorite structure of most players.

Abandoned Castles would be similar to the mansions already in the game. They could a dungeon filled with pillagers with a pillager lord guarding his treasure. You would buy a map from a cartographer as per usual and then travel to its location.

The castles can have a mix of always included and randomly spawning rooms. Random rooms could just be rooms that don't include any items that you cannot obtain in any of the other rooms. There should always be a ruined throne room and treasury. Random rooms could include: the guard quarters, guard towers, an armory, the servant quarters, a kitchen, the royal families rooms, the tombs, and dungeon.

The dungeon can contain captives that the pillagers have captured. These captive villagers will be captives until freed with the keys you can get after defeating the pillager lord. The reason for this is that you might not want a village to be spawned right underneath your new castle. you can attach a lead to the villagers while there captives so that you can create a village elsewhere.

Cheep loots like rotten flesh and string can be found anywhere in the castle other than the treasury. It will have valuable loot, such and gems, ingots, armors, weapons, and rare enchanting books ( like the frost walker enchant ).

There can also be haunted castles with specters and evokers lurking in its depths. An evoker boss would be guarding access to the treasury instead of a pilager king. The treasury in these castles could include worse loot, but also contain potion and enchanting supplies that the evokers were keeping.

I think if this were to be implemented they should be fairly rare. A sprawling ruin of a castle, as aforementioned, is something that many builders aspire to create and spend many hundreds of hours upon. Although I don't think they should be quite as rare as, say, the woodland mansion, it should be comparable.

Unfortunately, one major gripe about the woodland mansion is that it is pretty optional, and doesn't really incentivize players to spend an inordinate amount of time reaching such a place. So in regards to loot, the castles should guard important treasure - why else would they have been built? I think it would be extremely interesting if castles were stronghold variants that held an end portal in its basement, a subtle nod to Fallen Kingdom, or perhaps stockpiles of gold, iron, or diamond blocks would suffice as reward enough.

I think that, for a mountain castle, it could also be the opportunity to add interesting mobs and mechanics exclusive to the castle area. Perhaps the guard towers could be stationed with strays? Perhaps frozen zombies, or trolls could defend the castle from exterior invaders. Would ballistae be out of play? Maybe stone golems could guard the castle perimeter, similar to how Hogwarts was defended by its army of stone knights, or how the ancient Chinese built mausoleums of terracotta warriors to protect their dead emperor.

I think this would be good as long as it isn't too "mod-like."

I absolutely love playing modded Minecraft, and I also enjoy mods like Rogue-Like Dungeons.  These add very elaborate and deep dungeons with structures that are fun to explore.  They add custom spawners which get more and more difficult as you go deeper.  The problem though is that they never fit in with vanilla, because the level of depth that is found in those is more than that of vanilla structures.  At the same time it doesn't fit in because there isn't enough depth.  

Overall, this is an amazing idea that I think the team should accept and work on.  Things to look out for and experiment with are size and depth, both on the y-axis and the depth of detail in the castle.  I think this would be great as maybe another large structure or maybe a mountain village.  It could be the mountain equivalent of the Bastion or Dark Oak Mansion.  Avoid making it too similar to those though, and as usual be careful with it, try to strike the same balance you found with the Bastions and Abandoned portals, where they don't feel modded and feel natural.

I think that it would be cool to have different types of castle variants, 
The Watch tower, which can maybe just be the pillager outposts but there isn’t a village nearby.
Then the castle wall, which can spawn in any biome, but it is a bit more rare than a desert temple.
Finally a castle, these can spawn in Mountain, Tundra (and tundra variants) and Iceberg biomes. They can be made of different materials depending on where they spawn, so cobblestone in mountain, stone and Ice in tundra and Snow and Ice in Iceberg biomes. The castle would be decently rare, but have mobs like the Yeti and different  Illigers guarding it. This would be a great place to have the underused Stray, and unofficially added mob illusionar into the game. Then at the top of the castle there could be a dragon at the top, like a mini boss, it could be slightly smaller, shoot fire and have much less health than the Ender Dragon. When the Dragon is killed it could leave its egg unguarded and you can hatch the dragon and tame it, to keep as a pet. Because I think Minecraft could use a flying mob that you can ride. When you are not ridding the dragon it will shoot fire at hostile mobs, but do much less damage than the previous hostile dragon. The Castle can also have a few mob spawners, and have a broken Nether or End portal, along with dungeons, treasure room and other rooms in the dungeon and surrounding castle.

Ruined Structures come in 5 sizes, camp, tower, fort, keep, and castle. Ruined soldier variants of zombies and skeletons live in these places, travel in raiding parties, and don't burn in daylight. Raiding Parties set out from any ruined structure, the bigger the structure, the bigger the Raiding Party. Raiding Parties can set siege to Villages. Unless you have conquered and defeated a ruined structure, when you try to sleep in its vicinity a message will display saying: "You don't feel safe here" There will be Shattered Stone in the Ruined Structure. Shattered Stone breaks if you stand on it for too long.

Ruined Structures can upgrade to the next level structure with enough time and Ruined Soldiers. Camps are set up by Raiding Parties anywhere. Towers are set up when some Raiding Parties conquer a Pillager Outpost. Forts are set up when some Raiding Parties conquer a Village and have a miniboss called the Ruined Knight. Keeps have 1 dungeon layer with a Stone Golem miniboss and a Ruined King boss in the grand hall upstairs. Castles are just like keeps except they have an outer courtyard with a wall surrounding it. Castles also have a 2nd dungeon level where there is a Stone Monster Boss that can be awakened. 

The first time you visit a Keep/Castle you will find the Ruined King in the Grand Hall. If you fight him and lose, the next time you arrive at the Keep/Castle there will be more Ruined Soldiers and you will have a high chance of meeting and fighting in an encounter.

I agree with the need to have reliable access to nether fortresses, but I also agree with the need for nether exploration and fortress rarity. So, as gremwave mentioned in a previous comment, adding an alternative way to find nether fortresses would be an excellent way to reduce the random nature of obtaining critical fortress-sourced items while still encouraging extensive exploration of the nether.

Possible options:

1. Assorted audio cues when looking in the direction of a fortress if the player does not have the achievement related to entering a fortress for the first time

2. Compasses point to fortresses when within x/z blocks of one by default (overridden by lodestones).

 

P.S.

Personally, I am in favor of limiting fortress spawns to farther out than an x/z-block radius from the first point where the nether is loaded (similar to the first ring of stronghold spawns), but that suggestion might be more suited for a different thread.

Alternatively, given that nether fortresses are so broken up, there could be smaller bits of nether fortress ruin scattered more commonly throughout the nether, sometimes containing leftover netherwart.

Blazes could then uncommonly spawn in the basalt delta, since the only thing that spawns there currently are magma cubes.

Agreed, I'd like a major redesign of the villages. Maybe with doors on what the structure generator considers "houses" and torches in what the village behavior considers "houses". The big L shaped house has a huge dark area that zombies can spawn in, and the ones with decent lighting have no doors. That being said, I wouldn't so much change the floor layout of these structures at all. More so the composition of the building and interior design. Because 1.13 has given us nice stripped logs, 1.6 had hay bales that could potentially be used as thatch (especially with the new texture), corner stairs have been a thing for the longest time, and ceramic bricks have existed even before villages were implemented. 

As for nether fortresses, more use of stairs and red brick please. Maybe even some slabs for the roof so that mobs don't amass on top of the hallways. Same thing with the Woodland mansion, though outside of brick roofs not much needs to change. Same with the exterior of ocean monuments, because prismarine stairs were just implemented and aren't used for at least minimal detailing. Outside of that they're pretty decent.

And I get that the one thing Jeb_ and Notch regretted making during early development was the slab and stair "pseudo blocks" but they are the best thing that could have happened for architecture. The one thing I despise them making is those ugly raw igneous stone blocks. More for the fact that seem to pepper the underground with mostly clashing colors. I honestly would have made them alternate pallets for the default stone.

I can agree with this except for the villages, the old villages look a bit too plain and similar.  The variety in the old village buildings are almost non-existent.  The palette they used is a bit too, lets say, not unique.  Many players already uses mostly cobblestone and wood/logs to build their homes, and I don’t think players are getting too much inspirations from these.  With the new village remodel, I as a builder myself too started to think about: what can I do to make my builds blend in or contrast the environment better?  What is possible with the resources that are available in this area?  And most importantly, what kind of style suits the surroundings?  While yes, they still aren’t grand or monumental, but this is just a beginning for a new era for villages.  I can be very sure that this isn’t anywhere close to their final forms just yet.  I can also say the same for all the other overlooked structures.  I want the people to remember that these generated villages are meant to give inspirations to those who are new to building, and a challenges for adept builders to test their ability to rebuild wherever they see fit.

Here's a few of my thoughts on structures in general -

Overall, I think the game is nearing "Structure Fatigue" where there's far too many structures close by. Hoping for biomepacks soon to adjust structure frequency.

Dungeons - I feel like these were supposed to make caves more dangerous when they were first added. (there should be creeper spawners, BTW, and spawners should have a blast resistance like obsidian). At the very least, spawner mobs should have an AI tag that makes them flee the spawner room and head into the tunnels, plus have a larger stop/de-spawn radius from the player.

Mine-shafts - Should be less frequent at/near (1024x1024 blocks?). I find a good cave system more enjoyable than mine-shafts.

Ravines - FAR too common. I've seen worlds with 6-8 ravines within view distance of spawn using spectator mode (16 chunk render distance). However, with that being said, I would like to see wider ravines (maybe a biome where such a ravine would exist).

Shipwrecks & Ocean Ruins - would like to see these a little less, or larger oceans to make them less concentrated.

Maybe just a sight makeover, and make it a bit harder would be nice.

I don’t know if Mojang would listen to this but I’m 100% agree with this idea.

There are some really old structures in the game. New structures start from the end city use structure NBT to store (end city, mansion, igloo, ship reck, underwater ruin, new village and even the new Nether structures). But structures in pre1.8 are just not receiving any love.

My thoughts:

1. Ocean Monument:

Totally not worth visit at all. You need to traverse tons of guardians, and probably need a conduit or water breathing potions. This mean you have already visited the nether fortress or find a buried treasure. It’s somewhat difficult to traverse since those guardians spawned everywhere really do a lot of damage and they have a lot of health, BUT what do you get for clearing a Monument? Probably sea lanterns? And 8 gold blocks? Really, before 1.16 no one cares about gold and for post 1.16, 72 ingots are not rewarding enough. For technical players, the only use is to make guardian farm.

Suggestion:

Add chests of course! Now chests can be waterlogged and they look normal underwater so why not? Probably those chests are locked and keys can be find somewhere in the Monument (Locked chest is already a feature but is rather useless beside adventure maps, but in monument it’s a pain to break blocks so I think it fits).

Cont.

2. Desert Pyramid

This is the only structure I think worth visiting - It has 4 chests and that’s enough. 

Suggestion:

Make it in structure block. Slight re-design the exterior or give it some variations. Pre spawn mobs in the main room (husks). For the underground part, I think it would be cool to have random traps including the original one, but I don’t expect this to happen at all.

3. Jungle Temple

You get 2 chests from it so not too bad, but the design is really old and need improvements.

Suggestion:

Make it in structure block. Re-design the exterior and interior. Pre spawn mobs. Probably a jungle villager who is trapped inside?

4. Nether Fortress

I notice that fortress chests have significantly less valuable loot than other structures. Also, the generation of nether fortress is not exciting.

Suggestion:

Add more room types, make the loot more impressive. Use the new added nether blocks.

5. Dungeon

Cmon, do you think it’s a dungeon? It’s a small box.

Suggestion:

Make it at least 9 times bigger. It should contain connecting rooms with spawners, pre spawned mobs and traps.

6. Mineshaft

I don’t know, just feel like it’s too old.

Suggestions

Need a lot more variations to make it look more like mineshaft. Generate more ores in mineshaft.
Perhaps there could be 2 or 3 variations of each, to make it more interesting.

The structure the most in need of a redesign is definitely the nether fortress. When compared to the bastions, their age begins to show. They were made back when Minecraft was a simplistic game, with simplistic, blocky structures. But Minecraft is not what it used to be. It has evolved overtime, and the more new content is added, the more the old stuff begins to clash with the new. The nether fortress is a required visit to beat the game, so I feel it deserves more love. The devs had their chance in 1.16 to do it, but the update was already too big, and completely rewriting a structure would take to long. The least they could do is rewrite its generation code, and perhaps add the new nether brick variants to it as well. Though, honestly speaking, I feel like they'd need a new look to truly fit into this new vision of Minecraft.

 

All that said, I have no idea when this update would come. Probably not with 1.17 though.

YES! I totally agree with this idea! Here's some ideas I came up with about specific structures:

- Jungle temples could be much more imposing, designed like an Aztec pyramid/temple complex and including challenging traps, puzzles, parkour, and a sprawling underground labyrinth. Maybe even some custom jungle-y blocks could be used, or smaller jungle ruins could appear around the temple?

- Dungeons could have more than one chamber (still being small relative to other structures), and look more ruined/run-down than they do now. Like collapsed walls, water/lava flowing through cracks, more different varieties of stone used in them, etc.

- Desert Temples would be more decorative and larger, with more traps in them, with different activation methods so the player has to stay on their toes. They could also be integrated into desert villages as well!

- Igloos could come in various sizes, just to add to the immersion. Possibly the larger sizes could be rarer/have larger potion chambers below them.

- Strongholds, while large and impressive, are still kind of boring/uniform. I suggest more stone varieties in their structures, 3d variations in the walls and floors, and several different sizes of corridors and rooms.

I would absolutely love to see generated structures updated in Minecraft; I think it would really add to the game's immersion! With the mineshafts starting to be overhauled, I have high hopes for this idea.

I agree strongly. The 1.14 redesign of villages and villagers really breathed new life into that structure, and I believe some other structures (like the Jungle and Desert pyramids especially) could easily take advantage of the powerful jigsaw block in their generation (as villages and bastion remnants do). Jungle pyramids could be trap-filled puzzle rooms with a hefty prize at the end (diamond or emerald blocks, maybe?). Desert pyramids could keep their explosive tendencies, but maybe they'd also have other rooms besides the main entry hall and 2nd floor.

This could very well be possible in the Wild Update. While a purely aesthetic update would be nice, there could be gameplay changes too... such as adding procedural generation to add a bit more randomness to temple traps/puzzles, or adding smaller structures of a similar style that generate around these structures to give them more context. (Such as little ruined pillars of mossy cobblestone/sandstone around jungle/desert temples.)
Implementing some ready-made community designs seems like such a no-brainer.

...The trouble is, it isn't just aesthetics- its predictability. When they were first added, the traps in the jungle temple or the desert pyramid might have been challenging- but at this point, everyone knows exactly how to react to them. (Compare this to the Woodland mansion- which could still use some tweaks- but has enough random generation to make it much more interesting.) All of the more recent structures have some element of randomness or modularity, so that you're not just getting the same thing over and over again.

...I'm sure we'll see something like this eventually, but it would be really cool if the Wild Update brought it about. Consider this not an opportunity to replace existing structures... but to enhance them, and to expand upon their existing designs.

Talking about an update for some structures, we have to talk about villages aswell.

Yes, they've got an update a few years ago, but still, I think it's time for some major changes.

First of all, many villages look more like a field with farly scattered houses and not like what a real village should look like. The average distance between the houses should be a lot smaller, so the village looks a bit more "packed". The "town centers" need a revamp too - it's just something like a small well or a bell, but what about generating a new building as a meeting point for the villagers? I'm thinking of a market hall or like that.

Secondly, the materials the villages are made of. Look at the plains. Cobblestone just doesn't look good on most houses. Change it to stone bricks. And then, add more wood types to the buildings. Why is it only oak in plains villages? Birch forests often aren't far away, so combine it with a few birch planks or stairs. Here are my idea to enhance existing structures, imagine the desert pyramid looming larger, its entrance a foreboding gateway filled with traps that threaten with TNT blasts, treacherous falls, and hidden quicksand. Inside, labyrinthine tunnels twist and turn, guarding the treasure with cunning. The jungle temple expands into a grand stone brick edifice, ancient and formidable. Poisonous arrow traps and cascading boulders challenge adventurers, culminating in a complex puzzle guarding its chest.

The stronghold’s ceilings arch higher, its corridors broadened to accommodate intricate rooms like a detailed portal chamber and an expansive library. The woodland mansion’s roof is redesigned, exuding grandeur without sacrificing its mysterious allure, while the nether fortress fortifies into a formidable stronghold with battlements and chambers, no longer mere pathways.

Borrowing from Greek architecture, the ocean monument rises majestically from the sea, its columns and domes evoking ancient splendor. The witch hut transforms into a picturesque abode, its details revealing a rich history. Abandoned mineshafts gain accessible ground-level entrances and a new quarry variation, offering new depths to explore and mine. Each enhancement enriches Minecraft's world, inviting players into deeper, more immersive adventures.
