I love ideas like this. Here is my revamp...

Caves no longer cut off ores(WAYYYY too often you just find 1 diamond in a cave) but instead, Anything it cuts off becomes ore crystals! Heres how generation would work.

-1st it generate the world

-2nd generates caves

-3rd generates ores. Any ores that occupy at least 1 block of "normal ore" in generation spawn in the rest of the ore pieces in ore crystals.

The outside of these crystals are ore shards, and yield double the normal amount of resources and xp as usual. In the case of gold and iron, it is automatically ingots and yields double the amount of furnace xp. Anything that is not covered by these shards form the main body of these crystals, the crystal blocks. Mining these yields triple. Note: balancing will ensue on these absurd rates(triple is "a little bit" too high), but the general idea is to make cave mining worth the risk.

If you mine these with silk touch, they yield the shard/block itself, which is super cool and a good building/lighting block.

I have ton of ideas for this concept, but let us start with the basics.

Types of crystals and the block spectrum
The crystal types are listed in this order. Crystal bud, growing crystals, crystal spikes, crystal growths, crystal base blocks, budding crystal base blocks, crystal spike blocks, and crystalizing stone and deepslate. The block spectrum is just like a normal cave biome, but add calcite. The generation of this biome is a normal caves biome layout bu t with an occational crystal geode, and crystal spikes ranging from a block large to the hight of the cave, skattered all over the place.

Crystal species
.amethyst
.overworld courtz
.emerald
.agate
.diamond
.ruby

Crystal uses
A normal crystals drop crystal shards, which can be used to make the lens, which when used, focuses light, but can also do damage to undead mobs as a weapon and lighting source. Shards can also be put in stone cutters to make normal cut crystal forms like the normal emerald, which can now be traded with villagers. Normal crystals can also be used in smithing tables to enhance gear. Crystal spike and base block can be crafted into shards. Crystal spikes are like dripstone. If you fall on it, you take damage, if it falls on you, you take damage. I love this idea, i just wanted to add some context to what might happen inside the biome itself.

I was about to create a post about undergroud villages but saw this post and thought I would leave my idea as a comment. Hopefully people enjoy it.

Underground Village

You are rafting down an underground waterfall when you fall in a massive lake. On the far side of the cavern, you see twinkling of yellow lights. It is an underground village and you begin paddling towards it.

Underground villages occasionally generate in large caverns underground. Made up of stone huts with some buildings being built into the walls of the cavern, these villages differ from normal villages in a few ways:

  • A new type of villager, called a miner, inhabits underground villages. Miners offer stone and ores such as iron, coal and copper. At higher levels, a miner will offer gold ore, Lapis lazuli, crystals and eventually sculk blocks and sensors.
  • A new type of golem called a cobble golem protects underground villages. Cobble golems are shorter than regular golems and can wander nearby underground tunnels. They are covered in glow berries illuminating their surroundings.
  • Underground villagers farm mushrooms and glow berries as normal crops will not grow underground.
  • Underground villagers hang lanterns around their villages to ward of aggressive mobs which might attack them.

Or maybe the inhabitants could be warlins, a humanoid that is half goblin and half warden like the one I saw at Minecraft Live. These creatures will hunt wardens for food, just like how piglins hunt hoglins for food. Also, you'll be able to trade with them using any stone like blocks(stone, cobblestone, basalt, blackstone, diorite, and granite.

I think the "villages everywhere" mentality is a bit flawed. People think it's "cool" to have underground villages, or whatever else, but they don't really add much.

Firstly, this idea doesn't make much sense. Why would the villagers actively choose to settle underground? They're clearly in a lot more danger of monsters all the time. Gonna need lots of golems. If they're a mining colony, it would make more sense to settle above ground with easy access to a mine instead.

They wouldn't really useful to the player. It doesn't seem like they're so much better than normal villages to make seeking one out worth it, and if they were it'd make the above-ground villages a heft less useful.

I feel like the underground is supposed to have a hostile vibe. You only find dangerous mobs down there (besides bats, but they actually make sense). There's no safe havens until you make one, as the player is far more capable of exploring the underground than the villagers. (I have more arguments, but character limit.)

It could make a bit more sense for the underground to be inhabited by the illagers instead. They're already pale and don't seem to like sunlight, and are much more capable of defending themselves. The underground would be a great place to hide and do their thing. Maybe the illusioner could hide in these underground settlements. Maybe if you've killed enough villagers or something, they'll become neutral toward you, and maybe be willing to help you out in exchange for some sort of labor.

Was going to post the same idea, but will add comments here instead.  I think beavers would be best if they weren't as overpowered as you suggest.

  • Rare spawn rate
  • Spawns in birch forests which are currently rather empty.
  • Requires a natural stream and a non-flat geography that could be flooded
  • Passive and untamable.
  • Thins out the forests, leaving behind birch trunks on the ground with bark intact.
  • Leaves behind planted birch saplings after it chews down a tree.
  • Turns streams into ponds or lakes using stripped birch wood for damming the stream.
  • The dam logs could slowly convert to soil leaving behind natural pond areas.
  • Would be best if they were combined with a change that allowed sticks to be placed as a block.
  • If you don't want stick blocks, then dead bushes might achieve the same look.
  • Makes a beaver hut
  • Tail slaps the water when it detects intruders, or when it plays around.
  • Flee into beaver hut when startled.
  • Could drop beaver tails that can be used for making aquatic armor if killed.
  • Beaver tail could be made into a soup/stew, or used for brewing.
  • Swimming animation, tree chewing animate, building, and stick dragging animations

Armor made from a new type of leather that has the durability of iron, but the defense of diamond AND a swim speed buff, an underwater mining buff, and infinite breath, is way way overpowered.

There are already enchants that accomplish these buffs anyway. This new armor is unnecessary.

Everything else checks out, but I think that killing beavers or breaking their dam blocks should have a small chance at dropping fish.

Further, beavers ought to have AI that actively seeks water flow blocks (not source blocks) within their immediate range and attempts to replace them with dam blocks, drawing from an internal inventory of dam blocks.

The beaver should have a means of breaking down nearby trees and turning the wood into dam blocks, adding to the internal inventory.

Thus the player could use a captured beaver to build a fish generator by providing the beaver a tree generator to replenish the internal inventory of dam blocks, a water source block next to air to create a water flow block to dam up, some method of destroying the newly built dam block (adjacent fire lit Netherrack, perhaps), and some method of gathering the drops from it.

I would love to see beavers in a biome vote offering to update the river biome.

Their AI could chop down any trees within X radius of their beaver lodge (similar to how a Farmer villager works within the radius of their work block), but they would not chew trees beyond that. This would create natural clearings around their homes that result in more varied terrain, while stopping them from becoming a forest-destroying pest. Beavers could be the mob that finally enable auto wood farming, as if a sapling is planted within their work radius, they will chop it down when it grows, dropping logs and stripped logs.

They should be completely untameable and bite through leads, which would prevent it being too easy to corrall the beavers into a full auto wood farm early-game.

I like the idea of a clay ball surrounded by wood blocks being part of a dam recipe, but if beavers are breedable and their lodges are craftable it could make expanding an auto tree farm infinitely way too easy. For the sake of game balance, perhaps it would be fairer if they weren't craftable and breaking their lodge with anything other than silk touch just dropped the sticks. Salmon could display a "leaping" behaviour loop next to dam blocks.

Another balancing mechanic to auto farms could be their schedule - since real beavers are nocturnal/crepuscular, perhaps they would only chop trees at night, meaning if you constantly slept in a bed to skip the night, you wouldn't see them chop down any trees.

Great idea for a new natural mob. Here are my suggestions:

- Beavers spawn in specific spots (beaver dams) which generate in rivers in/near birch forests

- They are untamable and neutral, but become hostile when being attacked

- They should have relatively high hp and damage such that they are hard to kill

- Beavers strip logs (e.g. max 2 blocks above the ground) within a certain area around their spawning spot. This gives the possibility for stripped log farms, but as with amethyst farms they can only be built in specific spots in the world. It would also make it a little easier to find the dams, since stripped trees become a sign of their presence
